sectionConfigJson.title: Help us understand cardiovascular disease risk.
sectionConfigJson.blurb: The Demo Heart Study studies health and genetic information to better prevent and manage cardiovascular disease risk.

sectionConfigJson.title: Why is this needed?
sectionConfigJson.blurb: Cardiovascular disease is a significant cause of death in the United States and worldwide. Current genetic studies and research may be limited in size, cultural diversity.

sectionConfigJson.title: Who can join?
sectionConfigJson.blurb:
Anyone who is:

* Living in the United States
 * Older than 18 years old
 * Comfortable filling out surveys in English or Spanish
.

steps.blurb: Answer eligibility questions and create your account.
Read the consent form and decide if you’d like to join the study.
Answer survey questions about you and your health.
Provide your mailing address so we can send a sample donation kit.

questions.question: What is the Juniper Heart Demo study?
questions.answer: Juniper Heart Demo is a nonprofit research initiative that enables individuals to contribute to cardiovascular research by sharing their samples, their clinical information, and their voices.

questions.question: Why are we doing this study?
questions.answer: Individuals are disproportionately affected by cardiometabolic diseases, including heart disease, stroke, and diabetes. Risk-enhancing factors for cardiovascular disease are still being developed, highlighting an awareness but distinct knowledge gap. Juniper Heart Demo aims to address this gap by creating a cohort of individuals, from whom survey and genomic data will be analyzed to further our understanding of cardiovascular disease risk.

questions.question: How can I participate?
questions.answer: If you are over 18 years of age, live in the United States, you can sign up by clicking [“Join”](/studies/heartdemo/join).

questions.question: What does Juniper Heart Demo do with the data?
questions.answer: Only data and/or specimens necessary for study conduct will be collected. The electronic data collected will be maintained in a secure location with appropriate protections including password protection, encryption, and/or physical security measures (locked files/areas). The specimens collected will be maintained in a secure location with appropriate protections (e.g. locked storage spaces, laboratory areas). Data and specimens will only be shared with individuals who are members of the IRB-approved research team or approved for sharing as described in the IRB protocol. Identifiers will be coded and access to files linking identifiers with coded data or specimens will be limited to the minimal necessary members of the research team. All staff are trained on and will follow the Mass General Brigham policies and procedures for maintaining appropriate confidentiality of research data and specimens. All electronic communication with participants will comply with Mass General Brigham secure communication policies.
